Mark Harmon's journey into the world of entertainment began with his passion for acting, which led him to pursue a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Theater from the University of Miami. Following this, he further honed his acting skills at the prestigious American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco.

Harmon's big break came in 1980 when he joined the cast of the successful television series, "Hill Street Blues," as Detective Joe Broadman. The show was a hit, garnering critical acclaim and numerous awards, including the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series. Mark's exceptional acting skills were further showcased in the iconic series "Magnum, P.I.," where he portrayed the role of Tom Sullivan, the younger brother of the titular character, Tom Magnum. The show aired for eight seasons from 1980 to 1988, captivating audiences worldwide.

Throughout the years, Mark Harmon has accumulated a diverse and impressive list of acting credits, with his notable film roles in movies such as "Blind Side," "Mystic River," "Pearl Harbor," and "Criminal Minds: The Movie." In addition to his film and television appearances, Harmon has also been a regular host of numerous shows, including "Totally Awesome," "The Taste," and "The Deadliest Catch."

One of the most iconic roles that has defined Harmon's career is his portrayal of Special Agent Leroy Jethro Gibbs in the hit CBS television series "NCIS" (Naval Criminal Investigative Service). First premiering in 2003, "NCIS" has become one of the longest-running and most successful drama series on television, earning multiple Primetime Emmy Awards and a dedicated fan base. The show's success has continued, with eight spin-off series following Gibbs and his team.
